today on hot Thai kitchen we are 
making had yai fried chicken

Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today we are 
making fried chicken but not any fried chicken

we're making the fried chicken that comes from 
my hometown where I was born and raised so it's

called gai tod had yai gai means chicken tod
means to deep-fry and had yai it's the name of

my hometown so hey hot idea is now nationally 
famous you can get them pretty much anywhere

in the country but today instead of using larger 
piece of chicken I'm just gonna do chicken wings

because wings are more fun so let's first take 
a look at our ingredients one and a half pounds

of chicken wings three tablespoons of soy sauce 
I'm using healthy boy brand mushroom soy sauce

one and a half tablespoon of sugar five cloves of 
garlic one to two cilantro roots roughly chopped

half a teaspoon of salt heaping quarter teaspoon 
of white peppercorns which is equivalent to about

half a teaspoon of ground white pepper heaping 
quarter teaspoon of black peppercorns which is

also about half a teaspoon of ground black 
pepper thinly sliced shallots about half a

cup and a quarter cup to half a cup of rice flour 
so first we're going to deal with our shallots now

we're going to deep fry our shallots and fried 
shallots is the must-have condiment it's not

the I thought hey without the fried shallots so 
but before before we fry them we're going to dry

them out first so I finly sliced them and I'm 
just going to lay it out on a paper towel and

we sprinkle a little bit of salt on them you 
can be quite generous because we're going to

dab out some of this and what we're doing right 
here is we are trying to get out as much of the

shallots water as possible because the drier 
they are before you fry them the easier it

is to crisp them up things that a crispy means 
they're dry and if they have a lot of water to

begin with they're going to take a while to fry 
and they might burn before they become crispy

so this helps so the salt will help draw out 
the moisture we're going to let us sit while

we're doing everything else and then when we go 
to fry them we'll DAP out some of that water so

now we're going to make the marinade for the 
chicken which is quite simple but incredibly

delicious we're going to start out with our garlic 
in there and then I'm going to also add all the

white peppercorns and black peppercorns now you 
might think this is a lot of pepper and it is and

that's why it's so good and we're also going to 
add our chopped cilantro roots now if I've made

this recipe before without the cilantro roots and 
it's still super delicious so if you can't find

some tree roots just leave it out not a big deal 
and I'm just going to pound it into a fine paste

okay so you want it to be a fine paste so we're 
going to transfer that into our ziploc bag because

that is what we're going to marinate our chicken 
in and it smells really good already we're going

to add the rest of our marinade ingredients which 
is salt or soy sauce and what else sugar our sugar

so the sugar in the marinade is the reason why our 
chicken is going to be a dark brown color rather

than the KFC golden color so the chicken I'm 
using chicken wings but you can also use larger

chicken I have removed the drive he'll remove 
the drum it's part but I'm leaving the wingtips

on because the wing tips when you fry them is 
really quite tasty actually like chewing on the

skin on the wing tips so we're just going to add 
our chicken here and I also like using chicken

wings because the reason why people like fried 
chicken is because of the skin and the wings have

the highest skin to meat ratio right so you know 
it's most bang for your buck okay so once that's

in I'm going to mix it a little just like that and 
I like doing it in a ziplock bag because you get

a lot of coverage this way for the marinade and 
then I'm going to add some water and the reason

being with more volume of the marinade it'll 
go so it'll cover the chicken more thoroughly

and it acts kind of like a brine so ask the 
chicken marinade some of the water will actually

go into the chicken making it super moist and 
juicy so there see how now there is a lot of

liquid so when we let this marinate it's going 
to cover a lot of chicken and not just it's all

going to be on the bottom so that's the purpose of 
the water and we're going to let this marinate for

about two to three hours at the least you can 
also do this overnight but if you're going to

do this overnight I recommend cutting down the 
salt to about a quarter of a teaspoon just so

that it's not too salty and halfway through the 
marinade flip the bag so that the marinade goes

to the other side so when that's done marinating 
we're going to go inside them okay so now we're

ready to fry our shallots but we're first going 
to take out all the water that it's given off

during the time that it's been sitting now if I 
had more time it will give off even more water

but it's better than nothing now so you can 
see on this paper it's taken out a little bit

of water and that's actually going to help out 
quite a bit when we go to fry them that's all

the water we don't have to try to fry off right 
so in different shallots by the way we'll have

different moisture content I think the bigger 
the shallots are the more moist they tend to

be so for this small shallots actually work very 
well we're frying it on low if we fry it too high

there won't be enough time for them to dry off and 
crisp up they'll burn before that so you want it

to be lazily frying all throughout the process 
until they're crispy and it's better to err on

the lower side then the higher side as far as 
heat goes so the bubbles are not bubbling right

away like you normally do with frying it's not 
a big deal it's better that then to have it be

too hot now I've seen people even start them in 
cold oil and then heat everything up together

the thing about these is in the first few minutes 
it looks like nothing is happening but as soon as

they start to brown slightly they'll go from brown 
to burnt very quickly I've read you so many times

hopefully I don't do it right now so it's very 
important to keep the heat under control and it's

very important to take them out before they reach 
that ideal brown color they're going to be quite

dark because their sugar in them so the sugar 
caramelizes of the brown color but just when

you think okay a little bit more in it's perfect 
take it out because the residual heat will keep

them cooking oh and keep stirring them because 
you want to make sure the heat distribution is

even this is why it's also very important to cut 
the shallots evenly the most dangerous thing is

to get impatient with them in the first few 
minutes and then turn up the heat to get them

going faster and then low burn and as the bubbles 
are slowing down that's also a sign that they're

nearing the point where they're dry and crispy 
because the bubbles is water coming out of the

shallots s or as the water is evaporating so when 
the bubbles are slowing down and your heat hasn't

slowed down that's when you know you're close okay 
I'm pushing it pushing it a little further okay

that's it I'm done come on see how they're still 
completely still now that means there's no more

water that's a good sign that we've managed the 
heat well that when it's done it's at the right

color and it's not bubbling anymore perfect okay 
so our chicken has been marinated and now I've

transferred it from the bag into this bowl and 
I'm going to add some rice flour which is going

to create essentially a light batter with the 
marinade and that's another purpose of the water

that we added is so that we have that the batter 
is a lighter batter it's actually optional some

vendors of Chi tot hat yeah it doesn't use any 
flour at all so to just be marinated chicken

and you just fry that which you could do but I 
think the added flour actually helps crisp up

the skin but you know whatever you want it's about 
a quarter of a cup to a half I usually add about a

quarter first stir it up and see the consistency 
add all of it ah too much that's kind of what

I'm looking for enough that it's a thin coating 
clinging on to the skin brilliant this is it okay

now we're going to fry oil 350 as per frying 
anything don't crowd the pan or you drop the

temperature too quickly okay and I also recommend 
not using the tongs you use for this to mess with

it in the pan because one you want to prevent 
cross-contamination and two you're going to end

up with a lot of cooked on batter on the tongs 
under be a nightmare to clean so so they should

take about five minutes four to six depending 
on the size of your chicken and so you want to

move them around as soon as they go in just so 
they don't stick to the pan they like to do that

so here's our beautifully fried they thought had 
the I it now to serve oh by the way our shallots

just so you get a closer look nice and beautifully 
golden brown and crispy okay so now to serve guys

hot had yeah is served a lot of times with sticky 
rice so you want to get a couple of pieces on here

this way I also like the leaving the wingtips on 
it makes it look a lot more elegance with stuff

pointing everywhere and we sprinkle the shallots 
a whole bunch on the chicken and then a little bit

on the sticky rice and the sticky rice is great 
for using it to stick the shallots in when you

put it in your mouth now dipping sauce you're 
wondering what kind of dipping sauce for these

I personally think you don't really need dipping 
sauce for this it's really quite good on its own

but if you're a dipping sauce kind of person 
you can use the same one that I made for my

shrimp cakes a couple of weeks ago and I'll put 
the link to that episode in the description as

well and basically that dipping sauce is great 
for anything that's deep-fried that's it I hope

you enjoyed the show and get to make these at your 
party or next event or at the Super Bowl which is

I'm not sure what but if you enjoy the show please

please visit Hawkeye kitchen comm and I will
